answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Yes, sir, there are some ordinances related to decorum and defamation. A warning and ruling out of order before ejection is common. A few ordinances are collected at:  http://www.generalcode.com/codification/sample-legislation/public-meetings 
"Rules of civil debate" in Santa Cruz and Muskogee  http://cityofsantacruz.com/Modules/ShowDocument.aspx?documentid=29322 
http://www.cityofmuskogee.com/images/uploads/dept_0123/01-02EXB.pdf 
Better to have a consistent set of guidelines on indecorous behavior than to appear capricious. I like the inclusion of tips for effective presentation for those who may never before have spoken in this way.  
We have all seen public meetings go by with zero public comment, and I appreciate a chair who tolerates some crude comment when it occurs, erring in favor rough and rowdy speech over no speech at all.

answers.author: Joseph Ohler
answers.text:
Why not have the Common Council adopt a municipal ordinance applying the state's disorderly conduct laws to the conduct of participants and audience members at public meetings? Sure, it might be a restriction on free speech, but most disorderly conduct laws remain on the books despite theoretical challenges.

author: David Ellis
text:
During the public comment period of a recent City Council meeting a few speakers elected to use inappropriate language during their presentation (lF-bombs and other words were used freely).  This was the first time it has occurred here and we are wondering if other jurisdictions have experienced this and if so how have you managed the situation.  
Thanks 
David
title: Citizen Conduct @ Council Meetings
